awd_titl_txt: Processing Mechanically Reliable Flexible Organic Electronic Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Processing Mechanically Reliable Flexible Organic Electronic Films

The development of printed electronics made with organic (carbon-based) semiconductor materials has resulted in several promising technologies including organic light emitting diodes for displays, solid state lighting, and organic photovoltaics. The advantages of organic electronic materials are their relatively low cost and availability compared with inorganic semiconductor materials. However, in general, the active layers and electrodes used in organic electronics can be susceptible to chemical reactions with water vapor and/or oxygen during use, thereby reducing their lifetime, efficiency, and overall performance. There is a critical need to develop advanced permeation barriers for assembling these devices given the role the packaging has in the reliability of the organic electronics and the ever-increasing demand for these products. These barrier films must also be mechanically robust (resist cracking) when large applied strains are imposed during use. This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge for the processing of mechanically reliable, ultrathin polymer barrier films processed with the atomic layer deposition technique. Additionally, summer enrichment programs are planned for high school students to encourage their interest in pursuing education and careers in STEM fields. 

The overarching goal of the proposed research is to provide a fundamental understanding of mechanical reliability of ultra-barrier films made by atomic layer deposition for application to flexible printed electronics.  The experimental protocol will explore the relationship between processing conditions, onset failure strain, and material composition/structure failures to elucidate the factors that impact the reliability of atomic-layered-deposited barriers used in flexible electronics.  These films differ from most atomic-layered-deposited film in that they are processed at temperatures below 100°C for compatibility with low cost substrates and/or sensitive organic electronic devices.  Thus, the stoichiometry of these atomic-layered-deposited films can be quite different than those processed at higher temperatures, resulting in properties that are not fully characterized or understood.  This research will provide a systematic scientific study to understand, predict and minimize cracking of low-temperature coatings, with a specific focus on the effects of processing conditions (temperature, chemical functionalization of the polymer substrates) on their barrier performance and mechanical properties. This will be enabled by coupling state-of-the-art mechanical testing with surface science and multi-scale modeling studies that will provide the link between the stoichiometry of the atomic-layered-deposited coatings, their hydrogen content, and the analyzed mechanical behavior.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this research was to develop a fundamental approach to improve the flexibility of brittle moisture barrier films that are used to protect flexible organic and thin film electronics.  At present, the majority of these barriers are made from materials like silicon nitride and aluminun oxide which are brittle and can crack when used in devices that are curved, bent, or folded.  Future devices may also include stretching (Figure 1).  Thus, the issue that must be resolved is whether there are fundamental technologies that will allow us to maximize the mechanical reliability of these films for flexible electronics. The fundamentals of fracture are guided mainly by the modulus of the film and substrate, the applied energy available to cause the crack to grow, the constraint that the substrate applies to limit cracks from opening under loading, and environmental factors (Figure 2).

In this work, we were able to demonstrate that a simple metric like crack onset strain or strain to failure is not sufficient to describe the mechanical reliability of barrier films made from silicon nitride.  This was done by applying a tensile test to silicon nitride coated on polymer substrates and watching the fracture process in-situ (Figure 3).  It was found that when the silicon nitride was loaded to strains below the onset crack strain, the cracks grew which shows that the damage is time dependent and evolves.  As seen in Figure 4, increasing temperature causes the cracks to grow faster as well as testing in air versus dry nitrogen.  In addition, there are a larger number of cracks that nucleate in air vs dry nitrogen.  Thus, there are both stress corrosion effects as well as temperature effects that cause cracks to propagate more quickly.  These are the first experiments to show time dependent failure in ultrathin (100 nm thick) silicon nitride barrier films.

After establishing a clear understanding of the fracture process and growth rates in silicon nitride barriers, we were able to create multilayer nanolaminates of alternating layers of silicon nitride and Cytop polymers.  This architecture was used to show that we could increase the strain to failure of the barrier from 1.7% to 2.5% strain which matched our modeling results (Figure 5).  Further improvements will require the development of barrier layers with increased fracture toughness in order to approach 5% strain levels for these films.  These results are the first to show that a modeling tool can be used to judiciously design and maximize the mechanical reliability of nanolaminate barriers for flexible electronics. 

The broader impact of this work resulted mainly through journal publications and presentations at conferences with the lead research student being female.  This work was dissemenated through six refered journal publications and eight confernece presentations.  This also led to interest from industry for understanding the reliability of commercial barrier films used in display products.  Finally, this work was able to seed additional collaborations on new barrier architectures on flexible substrates with colleagues at Georgia Tech and DOE laboratories.  The lead research student was able to complete her Ph.D. at Georgia Tech in the Fall of 2018 and will start her post-doc at MIT in Spring 2019.


Last Modified: 12/27/2018
Modified by: Samuel Graham

  • Image showing the factors that influence the fracture of brittle barrier films on flexible substrates.
    Samuel Graham
    Copyrighted

    Figure 2
  • Mechanical testing under a microscope (left) allows for the visualization of the fracture process, measuring crack speeds (top right) and crack growth rates vs applied energy (bottom right).
    Samuel Graham
    Copyrighted
    Samuel Graham
    Figure 3
  • Crack growth rates vs applied energy (left) showing that cracks grow faster with increasing temperature and in Air. (Right) Data showing the number of cracks that nucleate in air vs nitrogen for a given applied strain. Data shows that air is more detrimental than nitrogen for crack formation.
    Samuel Graham
    Copyrighted
    Samuel Graham
    Figure 4
  • Improvement in crack onset strain increased from 1.7 to 2.5%. Additional increases are limited by the cracking in the top SiNx layer.
    Samuel Graham

The intellectual merit of this research was to develop a fundamental  approach to improve the flexibility of brittle moisture barrier films  that are used to protect flexible organic and thin film electronics.  At  present, the majority of these barriers are made from materials like  silicon nitride and aluminun oxide which are brittle and can crack when  used in devices that are curved, bent, or folded.  Future devices may  also include stretching (Figure 1).  Thus, the issue that must be  resolved is whether there are fundamental technologies that will allow  us to maximize the mechanical reliability of these films for flexible  electronics. The fundamentals of fracture are guided mainly by the  modulus of the film and substrate, the applied energy available to cause  the crack to grow, the constraint that the substrate applies to limit  cracks from opening under loading, and environmental factors (Figure 2).

In  this work, we were able to demonstrate that a simple metric like crack  onset strain or strain to failure is not sufficient to describe the  mechanical reliability of barrier films made from silicon nitride.  This  was done by applying a tensile test to silicon nitride coated on  polymer substrates and watching the fracture process in-situ (Figure  3).  It was found that when the silicon nitride was loaded to strains  below the onset crack strain, the cracks grew which shows that the  damage is time dependent and evolves.  As seen in Figure 4, increasing  temperature causes the cracks to grow faster as well as testing in air  versus dry nitrogen.  In addition, there are a larger number of cracks  that nucleate in air vs dry nitrogen.  Thus, there are both stress  corrosion effects as well as temperature effects that cause cracks to  propagate more quickly.  These are the first experiments to show time  dependent failure in ultrathin (100 nm thick) silicon nitride barrier  films.

After establishing a clear understanding of the fracture  process and growth rates in silicon nitride barriers, we were able to  create multilayer nanolaminates of alternating layers of silicon nitride  and Cytop polymers.  This architecture was used to show that we could  increase the strain to failure of the barrier from 1.7% to 2.5% strain  which matched our modeling results (Figure 5).  Further improvements will require  the development of barrier layers with increased fracture toughness in  order to approach 5% strain levels for these films.  These results are  the first to show that a modeling tool can be used to judiciously design  and maximize the mechanical reliability of nanolaminate barriers for  flexible electronics. 

The broader impact of this work resulted  mainly through journal publications and presentations at conferences  with the lead research student being female.  This work was dissemenated  through six refered journal publications and eight confernece  presentations.  This also led to interest from industry for  understanding the reliability of commercial barrier films used in  display products.  Finally, this work was able to seed additional  collaborations on new barrier architectures on flexible substrates with  colleagues at Georgia Tech and DOE laboratories.  The lead research  student was able to complete her Ph.D. at Georgia Tech in the Fall of  2018 and will start her post-doc at MIT in Spring 2019.
